title: Investigating a Tragedy: The Inquest into Chimamanda Adichie's Son's Death
summary: This article reports on the upcoming inquest into the death of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's 21-month-old son, Nkanu Nnamdi Esege, who died at Euracare hospital in Lagos, Nigeria, on January 7. The inquest, set to begin on April 14 at the Yaba Magistrate Court, aims to determine the circumstances and cause of death. Adichie and her family have accused Euracare of negligence, alleging that medics denied Nkanu oxygen and administered excessive sedation, resulting in cardiac arrest. In contrast, the hospital has expressed condolences but denied any wrongdoing, asserting that their care adhered to international standards. During a preliminary hearing, Magistrate Atinuke Adetunji directed all parties to submit witness statements. The court will hear evidence from medical experts and hospital representatives as part of the coroner's investigation. Nkanu was initially admitted to Atlantis Hospital with a mild illness and was referred to Euracare for pre-flight tests, including an MRI and spinal tap, before a planned transfer to Johns Hopkins Hospital in the US. Adichie, an award-winning novelist known for works like 'Half of a Yellow Sun', is based in the US but was born in Nigeria. This case highlights issues of medical accountability and legal processes in healthcare disputes.
